bibl.title: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Albert E. Truby, January 2, 1936

div1.p: Sawyer inquires about the use of a rhesus monkey in Reed's yellow fever experiments. He questions the accuracy of the "Yellow Jack's" portrayal of Dean.

div1.head: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Albert E. Truby, January 2, 1936
div1.opener:

RUFUS COLE, M.D., CHAIRMAN

WILBUR A. SAWYER, M.D.
WILSON G. SMILLIE, M.D.
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH DIVISION
49 WEST 49th STREET, NEW YORK
CABLE ADDRESS: ROCKFOUND, NEW YORK
January 2, 1936.
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
I was talking with Dr. F. F. Russell while
he was in New York during the holidays and he suggested you
might be able to answer a question I asked him regarding the
experiment of the Reed Commission on a Macacus rhesus monkey.

In 1912 Dr. Agramonte published a brief note
in the NEW YORK MEDICAL JOURNAL saying that in 1901 a monkey of
the above species named Jenny was inoculated three successive
times through the bites of infected mosquitoes but remained re-
sistant. In our files we have a letter from Dr. Agramonte
written shortly before he died, in which he mentioned the fact
that the animal was probably immune. The presumption is that
the monkey was obtained locally and I wonder if you have any in-
formation regarding the source of the animal and the probability
of its having been immunized in Havana by naturally acquired in-
fection. This matter has interested me as showing how very near
the Army Board came to discovering a satisfactory experimental
animal and advancing the progress of yellow fever research by
another quarter century.

There is another question which I would like to
ask some one who was in Cuba at the time of the Army Board's ex-
periments. In the play, “Yellowjack” there were some inaccuracies
-2-
regarding the work of our commission in Africa and I presume the
same would be true regarding the work of the Army Board. Most
of them did no harm, but there was a very strong inference that
the soldier Dean was tricked into exposure to mosquitoes and had
no idea that there was any danger involved. I have been asked by
a number of persons who have seen the play whether this was true
and have stated I assumed that it was not, but had no first-hand
evidence and had seen no discussion of the point in any of the
publications.

If you can give me information regarding the above I
shall appreciate it greatly.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W A Sawyer General Albert E. Truby
Army Medical Center
Washington, D.C.
